original_title: Europa Clipper Asks Big Questions of the Jovian Moon
original_content:
Are we alone? While we certainly have lots of strange lifeforms to choose from as companions here on our blue marble, we have yet to know if theres anything else alive out there in the vastness of space. One of the most promising places to look in our own solar neighborhood is Europa.
Underneath its icy surface, Europa appears to have a sea that contains twice as much water as we have here on Earth. Launching later this year and arriving in 2030, NASAs Europa Clipper will provide us with our most up-close-and-personal look at the Jovian Moon yet. In conjunction with observations from the ESAs Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer (JUICE), scientists hope to gain enough new data to see if the conditions are right for life.
Given the massive amounts of radiation in the Jovian system, Europa Clipper will do 50 flybys of the moon over the course of four years to reduce damage to instruments as well as give it windows to transmit data back to Earth with less interference. With enough planning and luck, the mission could find promising sites for a future lander that might be able to better answer the question of if there actually is life on other worlds.
Some of the other moons around Jupiter could host life, like Io. Looking for life a little closer? How about on our nearest neighbor, Venus, or the ever popular Mars?
title: ヨーロッパ探査：NASAの新ミッション
body: 人類は孤独なのか？地球には多くの奇妙な生物がいますが、宇宙の広大な空間に他に生命が存在するかどうかはわかっていません。NASAのエウロパ・クリッパーは、木星の衛星エウロパを探索し、生命の可能性を調査します。
titles: ヨーロッパ探査：NASAの新ミッション
木星の衛星ヨーロッパ：生命の可能性
NASAのヨーロッパクリッパー：月面調査ミッション
土星の衛星探査：生命の可能性を調査
宇宙での生命：木星の衛星を中心とした調査
